```html

Variables:

  • Gestational age: 24+0 weeks, 34+6 weeks
  • Planned caesarean birth: Yes, No
  • Imminent preterm birth anticipated: Yes, No
  • PPROM: Yes, No
  • Delayed birth for antenatal corticosteroids: Yes, No
  • Time of first dose within 48 hours prior to birth: Yes, No
  • Time of first dose within 24 hours of birth: Yes, No
  • Tolerance for up to 5 days after administration in diabetic women: Yes, No
  • Birthweight reduction if birth occurs more than 7 days after steroids: Yes, No
  • Benefits if birth is more than 7 days after starting treatment: Yes, No
  • Increase in psychiatric and behavioral diagnoses in term-born children: Yes, No
  • Multiple pregnancies: Yes, No
  • Effects of unnecessary antenatal corticosteroids: Described, Not described
  • Respiratory support reduction: Yes, No
  • Neonatal hypoglycemia increase: Yes, No
  • Uncertainty for reduction in RDS, TTN, or NNU admission: Yes, No
  • Rescue course for reduction in need for respiratory support: Yes, No
  • Dose effects seen for harms: Yes, No
  • Repeat courses of antenatal corticosteroids: Yes, No
  • Risks of RDS and IVH reduction with corticosteroids: Yes, No
  • Recommended dose and route of administration: 24mg dexamethasone phosphate / intramuscular, 24 mg betamethasone sodium phosphate/acetate mix / intramuscular
  • Risks for fetal growth, neonatal hypoglycemia, and long-term development: Yes, No
  • Use when minimum standards of care are available: Yes, No
  • Reduction in neonatal death with antenatal corticosteroid use: Yes, No
  • Systemic infection presence: Yes, No
  • Immune suppression risk for systemic infection: Yes, No

Antenatal corticosteroids given within seven days prior to preterm birth reduce perinatal and neonatal death and respiratory distress syndrome. For women undergoing planned caesarean birth between 37+0 and 38+6 weeks, an informed discussion should take place about the potential risks and benefits of antenatal corticosteroids. Corticosteroids should be offered to women between 24+0 and 34+6 weeks' gestation in whom imminent preterm birth is anticipated. Antenatal corticosteroids should be offered to women with preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM). Birth should not be delayed for antenatal corticosteroids if the indication for birth is impacting the health of the woman or her baby. Antenatal corticosteroids reduce neonatal death when the first dose is given within 48 hours prior to birth. Benefits are also seen when the first dose is given within 24 hours of birth.

```
